body_html:
Thanks for pointing this out.

As outlined in our versioning guarantees policy, things in the tf.contrib namespace are considered experimental and subject to change.

So we allow for differences between say tf.estimator and tf.contrib.learn, as a means of learning from feedback on functions and classes in tf.contrib before settling down on an API we will provide stability guarantees for going forward (tf.estimator in this case).

In the long term, the tf.contrib symbols will go away (as we either figure out that they are not worth pursuing or adapt them into ones that we will support in a non-contrib module).

Hope that makes sense.

Thanks!

(FYI @ispirmustafa for this particular case)

Thanks for pointing this out.
As outlined in our versioning guarantees policy, things in the tf.contrib namespace are considered experimental and subject to change.
So we allow for differences between say tf.estimator and tf.contrib.learn, as a means of learning from feedback on functions and classes in tf.contrib before settling down on an API we will provide stability guarantees for going forward (tf.estimator in this case).
In the long term, the tf.contrib symbols will go away (as we either figure out that they are not worth pursuing or adapt them into ones that we will support in a non-contrib module).
Hope that makes sense.
Thanks!
(FYI @ispirmustafa for this particular case)
body:
Thanks for pointing this out.

As outlined in our [versioning guarantees policy](https://www.tensorflow.org/programmers_guide/version_compat#what_is_not_covered), things in the `tf.contrib` namespace are considered experimental and subject to change.

So we allow for differences between say `tf.estimator` and `tf.contrib.learn`, as a means of learning from feedback on functions and classes in `tf.contrib` before settling down on an API we will provide stability guarantees for going forward (`tf.estimator` in this case).

In the long term, the `tf.contrib` symbols will go away (as we either figure out that they are not worth pursuing or adapt them into ones that we will support in a non-`contrib` module).

Hope that makes sense.

Thanks!

(FYI @ispirmustafa for this particular case)
